'''The Gift''' was the name given to a number of concepts related to a person's innate natural aptitude for [[the Art]] of magic, and their ability to connect to and draw on the [[Weave]].{{Cite web/theedverse/2024-02-05 - Giftless Castings}}
{{quote|Play with magic and learn how best to wield it, but remember always that magic is an Art, the Gift of the Lady, and that those who can wield it are privileged in the extreme.|Fragment of the dogma of [[Mystryl]] and of [[Mystra (Midnight)|Mystra]]<ref>{{cite book/Forgotten Realms Campaign Setting 3rd edition|247}}}}
document_data.Testing: Temples usually tested for the Gift by casting an [[orison]], while wizards taught a prospective Gifted the workings of a minor, safe, and simple [[cantrip]] and observing the results.
document_data.Use in Magic:
In its most extreme formulation, sages spoke of the Gift as the ability to call on the Weave, and it was seen as necessary to employ any arcane magic at all,{{Cite web/theedverse/2021-05-19 - Wizards VS Clerics}} but it referred also to the ability to manipulate divine energy, and in fact some other abilities, with sufficient deftness to devise new spells and manage them appropriately. In such a view, a [[cleric]] or [[druid]] without the Gift would not be in control of their own spells available, nor would they be able to research novel magics, while a [[warlock]] would be similarly limited in spells to only those their patron actively provided.{{Cite_archive/Greenwood's_Grotto/2023-07-28/Giftless magic learners}} While all wizards wielded the Gift by definition, those from beyond Toril who operated methods not tuned to call on the Weave were not guaranteed that all their spells would behave exactly the same.{{Cite web/theedverse/2022-01-07 - Otherworldly Wizardry}}

Those with the Gift who would go on to wield magic would most likely train to become wizards.{{Cite web/theedverse/2021-10-21 - Becoming a Wizard}} One of the important skills of wizardry, the threefold task of visualizing the specific effects and the symbology inherent to the [[somatic component]]s, which was part of casting a spell, could be learned and used to at least activate items that themselves provided a connection to the Weave, even if one did not have such a connection on their own.
document_data.Other Effects: People without the Gift wouldn't be able to comprehend the sense of magical words chosen for an incantation, while those with the Gift would intuitively understand the sense and purpose of the words in the spell, even if they were not familiar with the languages selected by the spellcraftsman.{{cite web/Questions for Ed Greenwood/2008/10-27 - Spell Notation}} The Gift also allowed "voices in the Weave" to speak to its bearers.{{Cite web/theedverse/2021-11-21 - Shandril as a Voice}} Some people had "[[innate talent]]s" alongside their Gift or as its entirety, the ability to cast certain spells or use other effects without the need for any practice.{{Cite web/Ed Greenwood's Patreon/How Magic Works}}
document_data.Giftless Magic:
A few methods of magic, such as [[table magic]], didn't require the Gift.{{Cite web/theedverse/2021-02-13 - Table Magic}} As the Gift was a connection to the Weave,{{cite web/Candlekeep Forum/Questions for Ed Greenwood (2006)/07-10 - Incarnum and Truespeak}} and [[pluma]].{{Cite web/Candlekeep Forum/Questions for Ed Greenwood (2005)/09-27 - Consequences of Weave Failure}}

For those without the Gift, some powerful magic items (mostly artifacts) could provide a pathway to working magic.
